Award.AwardTitle: REU SITE: Research on Biomedical Informatics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a CISE REU program entitled Research on Biomedical Informatics at the University of Massachusetts Lowell. The objectives of this program are to expose students to the concepts, techniques, applications, excitement and rewards of Computer Science (CS) and Biomedical Informatics research, to stimulate the students interests in these fields, to improve students research and communication skills, and to encourage them to pursue a career in Computer Science. This program also allows a diverse group of talented undergraduates to gain valuable research and communication skills and improve self-confidence, creative thinking, and independent problem solving.

The REU Site program supports the research activities of ten undergraduate students per year for a nine week period. Each student project is derived from on-going faculty-led research projects. The research activities in this proposal will contribute to the understanding of the fundamental theory, principles, and techniques in data mining, information retrieval, networking, security, and privacy. Immediate impacts of these research activities include: (1) enhanced and supported decision making and data mining for clinicians and biomedical researchers; (2) new computing resources for the biomedical network platform and telemedicine; and (3) new protections against potential security breaches leading to improved patient privacy and safety. The research areas in this REU Site program cover some of the most challenging research questions in Biomedical Informatics, and each project has the long-term potential to improve the quality of health care, reduce medical errors, provide safer care at a lower cost, and advanced biomedical research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project is reflected in each individual research project. By engaging a diverse pool of talented undergraduate students in developing large-scale, high-performance, user-centered, and intelligent biomedical informatics solutions, the research activities in this proposal contributed to the understanding of the fundamental theory, principles, and techniques in data mining, information retrieval, networking, security, and privacy. Immediate impacts of our research activities include: (1) enhanced and supported decision making and data mining for clinicians and biomedical researchers; (2) new computing resources for the biomedical network platform and telemedicine; and (3) new protections against potential security breaches which lead to improving patient privacy and safety.

This project helped prepare  a workforce of young scientists in Computer Science. The REU students were trained in Biomedical Informatics, which plays a vital role in transforming health care, biomedical research, and education by improving the quality of health care procedures, reducing medical errors, lowering healthcare costs, and advancing biomedical research and education. This project allowed a diverse group of talented undergraduates, many from predominantly undergraduate institutions with limited research programs, to gain valuable research and communication skills, including self-confidence, creative thinking, and independent problem solving.

During our project period, we were extremely successful in attracting a diverse group of talented undergraduate students. Our program was also very successful to expose students to intensive and meaningful research experiences, as well as in stimulating students’ interests in CS research and encouraging them to pursue graduate studies and research careers in CS.
